awd_titl_txt: SCC-PG: Building capacity for data-driven physical activity interventions in communities with depression and obesity hotspots
awd_abstract_narration:
According to the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention, more than 40% of adults with depression are obese and adults with depression are more likely to be obese than adults without depression. Combined together, depression and obesity are two of the most common public health problems in the United States. Yet, effective exercise programs that help people to lose weight and cope with depression symptoms do not always reach communities with the greatest need. Mining data through electronic health records (EHR) and digital health technology can help to improve the reach by identifying communities most affected by obesity and depression. Once identified, engaging those communities is critical to informing locally-tailored interventions that will be adopted. The purpose of this project is to build capacity for combining health data analytics with community engagement efforts to identify, and design better interventions for, communities facing obesity and depression. 

This project (1) integrates heterogeneous data sources, machine learning, and geospatial analysis to identify geographical areas with high levels of depression and obesity called community hotspots, and (2) engages community members from hotspots to co-design desired physical activity interventions. Project findings will advance the field by yielding new ways for hotspot detection based on diverse real-world data and community-level intervention design while laying the technical and collaborative foundations necessary for future success. Technical contributions include novel data analytic methods, data sources, and metrics for hot-spotting using regional EHR data. Collaborative partnerships developed through this project will guide future extension of engagement to a broader number of community hotspots. More broadly, this work will benefit society through a data-driven, community-partnered approach that improves the health and wellbeing of citizens by addressing two of the most significant US health problems: depression and obesity.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.
org_dir_long_name: Directorate for Computer and Information Science and Engineering
org_div_long_name: Division Of Computer and Network Systems

por.por_cntn:
The major outcomes of this project are two-fold. First, real-world data from electronic health records holds promise for tracking healthcare equity by geographic region. However, this data may not equitably represent local regions and populations, impacting these efforts. Our work to explore novel data analytics methods to identify local obesity and depression ?hotspots? led us to develop a data pipeline for assessing geographic bias. The pipeline uses electronic health records to identify patients with specific health conditions (e.g., depression and obesity), and then maps patients? zip code locations on a map. This analysis allows helps assess geographic spread and representation to inform health equity interventions, such as social vulnerability index of highly impacted neighborhoods. Our pipeline highlights the importance of accounting for geography to guide the targeted deployment of limited healthcare resources and generate equitable and representative real-world evidence. 

Second, our work to engage ?hotspot? communities in surveys and  surveys and interviews indicates that people from socially vulnerable communities with comorbid depression and obesity want to exercise more and are interested in using technology to do so. Our findings identified unique physical activity barriers at personal, social, and neighborhood levels. We also identified opportunities for technology-based physical activity interventions that account for the community context. Because we focused on a community with a high prevalence of obesity and depression as well as a high social vulnerable index, these findings differ from prior research focused on individuals from communities with fewer social vulnerabilities. These findings provide insights for researchers and practitioners to consider when developing and evaluating health interventions, particularly for individuals from socially vulnerable areas.

These project outcomes advance knowledge in the field of biomedical informatics by providing novel data analytic methods for assessing geospatial bias in electronic health record data. Project outcomes also advance the field of human-computer interaction by informing community-tailored physical activity interventions that address barriers experienced by individuals in socially vulnerable neighborhoods. Given the need to both increase physical activity and address exercise barriers faced by those from socially vulnerable communities, findings offer broader impacts that benefit society by identifying community-level insights to support those who experience two significant US health problems: depression and obesity.

More generally, the project addressed educational goals of interdisciplinary cross-collaboration among clinicians, researchers, and trainees at undergraduate, MS and PhD levels in biomedical informatics, engineering, and health sciences. This project provided research opportunities for team members from underrepresented racial and/or gender groups in science and technology fields.  This experience has the potential to improve their inclusion and retention in research, teaching, and practice.  

 


Last Modified: 11/22/2022
Modified by: Andrea Hartzler
